reviewText:
Allow me to preface this by saying that I adored Vox Populi Vox Dei 1. I played it all the time in high school and loved it, it was a welcome change of pace from the standard flash platformers that overwhelm the market and was challenging, but still fair. I'm also a seasoned veteran of the platformer genre.

With that out of the way I need to state that Vox Populi 2 is not Vox Populi 1.

VP1 was a puzzle game with a side-scroller facade. There were minor platforming elements, but on the whole the game's focus was progressing past the baddies in your way by a means of stealth, planning and timing. Platforming mechanics like death pits and jumping gaps took a backseat to the design elements of the game.

VP2, however, tosses most of this out the window and stages itself like your typical indie platforming game. It has spike traps, projectile hazards, and jumping puzzles. A lot of the game relies on trial and error and sheer persistence to get through, so much so in fact that I feel compelled to compare it to I Wanna Be the Guy".

At this point
recommended: the story feels almost negligable. While the first game's plot was simple yet engaging
hoursPlayed: the story to this point has taken so many twists and turns that it feels more like a parody then something I'm interested in seeing through to the end.\n\nThe learning curve is pretty relentless as well: I found myself dying more than dozens of time on the first level of platforming. Maybe I'm just rusty
voteText: but I'm more inclined to blame the game's controls. They're simply not tight enough for the kind of precision platforming that VP2 demands of it's player. They feel slippery and it takes too long in some cases to get the horizontal momentum you need to be making it from platform A to platform B
helpfulPercent: which is why I found myself needing to take most of the jumps while hanging off the edge of platform A to compensate. In a game where you need to be making sudden stops and precise landings the controls should be built to match it.\n\nAttacking werewolves also feels much less rewarding because of the controls
votesHelpful: since mashing the space bar to do it at maximum speed is no longer an option. It seems to me to be because the player character can make another slash at his enemy after the previous attacking animation has ended. This makes the mashing feeling of destroying another creature feel far less rewarding and take the same amount of time every time instead of spurting blood on every key press a-la VP1.\n\nThe level design is poor as well. There are many cases in which you'll be committing to blind jumps and falls
votesTotal: relying primarily on the level to give you a checkpoint or platform to land safely onto. Even the spacing of checkpoints is relentless
votesFunny: one of the first jumping segments has you complete six different finicky jumping segments before allowing you a checkpoint.\n\nThere's another level early on where you encounter a machine stamping the floor of a hallway with spikes from above. By and large it's your standard 'wait until this hazard stops functioning before moving past it' type of timing puzzle
commentsCount: but it takes a good 10 seconds before complete its loop
column16: which feels far too long to be waiting around to study it's pattern. What's more is there are 4 of them
column17: each one is larger then the last and takes longer to complete as a result. Big elements of the design just feel poorly thought out at times which drags the gameplay to a screeching halt.\n\nThe design does attempt a few interesting turns later on when a stage uses it's blood particle mechanic to help the player see platforms. But for some reason it decides it needs a space shooter stage and a level that mirrors the player on the top and bottom half of the screen
column18: forcing you to keep both sides alive. On the whole it's nothing that hasn't been used in a platformer game before
column19: and to better effect then it achieves
column20: so the question remains as to why they would choose to implement it at all?\n\nDesign issues aside
column21: that's my main point of contention. I'm just left bewildered as to why the creators decided to scrap the puzzle formula to adopt a platformer approach. Vox Populi 1 was a game that used it's puzzle game design to great effect and I really was excited to see all the places a sequel could possibly go. However Vox Populi 2 just adapts to a saturated market and is just another platformer which makes the sequel immensely disappointing
column22:
and it's certainly not the game I was hoping for it to be.


-----------


tl;dr

If you're a fan of difficult indie platformer/action games and willing to lose one or two lives to design choices
column23:
this game may be for you.

But

If you're expecting a sequel to Vox Populi 2 in the same style of gameplay
column24: you may want to hold off on playing this one."

reviewText:
This game is weird. Super weird. One of the reasons you should buy it.

Other reasons:

*You play a ninja who murders werewolves who shoot lasers from their chest
*You murder a statue, a tree, and a giant lizard.
*You navagate a giant monster's intestines by popping its blood vessels and using the blood to reveal hidden blocks.
*The non-game (promotional, ect) art has an awesome Art Deco aesthetic, and who doesn't love Art Deco?
*It's cheap.
*It's challenging.
*If you buy it, they'll make an episode 3.

voteText: 20 of 25 people (80%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Vox Populi Vox Dei 2 does a good job at keeping the game fresh throughout levels. Make no mistake. This game is hard.
A Gameplay & Review video showcasing the features I will talk about
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x69ZYchAjSo
Killing enemies is satisfying as you mash the button to rip out their guts, and see blood with cool physics cover your environment.
The game doesn't always play music, but when it does, it makes moments that much better. The soundtrack is very cool.
There are bosses, which look cool but lack as much diversity as the rest of the levels. They mostly play the same way.

One of my favourite things about the game was how main gameplay mechanics constantly change. At one point you'll being doing some basic, but hard platforming. The next moment you'll be in a flying segment shooting at enemies ahead of you. The next will have you worry about 2 characters at once, running through asymmetrical levels for each.

I play hard platformers regularly, and am quite damn good at them. The first few levels were decently tough, but not much to get me frustrated. I'm a bit halfway now and the game is quite challenging. Not in a bad or frustrating way, which is good. The controls are very tight, so you don't feel cheated when you die.

Overall, it's a really cool little game that improves on everything from the first game. If you like the look of it, give it a try. It's really cheap after all.

reviewText:
I enjoyed this game quite a bit. It's a short but fun platformer.
There were a couple of hard sections, but nothing to make you pull your hair out.

The environments were great, and reminded me a lot of Another World (Out of This World).

I recommend playing the free flash version of Episode 1 just so you are caught up on the story, but it's not necessary.

I can't wait for Episode 3. :D

Edit: I forgot to mention, the music is amazing.
If they don't add it as a DLC, the bandcamp for the soundtrack is here: https://hernanmarandino.bandcamp.com/album/vox-populi-vox-dei-2-official-soundtrack

reviewText:
7.4/10 - Great Pixel Platformer with an Extra Side of Difficulty.

If you love challenging Pixel games; this is the one for you! This game relies on your skill, smarts and reflexes. Your character must constantly dodge weapon fire, boulders and tackle and kill wolfs in a charmingly bloody way.

This game will make you pull your hair out. The puzzles and objectives are simple enough but force you to do it flawlessly of you die and get sent to the last checkpoint. The checkpoints are few and far between so you really need to be on your A game.

Definitely worth the $3!

reviewText:
Product received for free

IntroductionDeveloped and published by Great Cogs, Vox Populi Vox Dei 2 (Latin for ‚Äúthe voice of the people is the voice of God‚Äù) is as the name suggests, a sequel. Unfortunately, the first one in the series (launched in 2009) is not yet available on Steam. I have played both for quite a few hours and I‚Äôm pleased to say that we‚Äôre dealing with a worthy sequel here, which only improves upon the foundation of the series. This may be Great Cogs‚Äô first game on Steam, but they managed to provide a fine pixelart platformer with plenty of gore and diversity. It most certainly stands out from your run-of-the-mill platforming games.

GameplayVox Populi Vox Dei 2 has medium-sized levels with both enemies (werewolves) and obstacles to pass through. The platforming sections are balanced with combat and several puzzles along the way. It may seem a bit difficult after the first few levels, as the game has boss fights and one of the few gameplay flaws, has to be the limited number of checkpoints found between the levels. It is true that the old school platformers had next to no saving system, but the mark of a modern game has to be it‚Äôs potential to pick up and also pause or leave the game state intact, between gaming sessions. This is indeed a game in which you get used to dying quite a lot so having to restart the level or even further than that, might become troublesome for some new players.

The game‚Äôs graphics are more than decent and the slightly limited color palette fits the atmosphere. The character sprites are well made and the many gory ways to die within the game provide ample animation diversity. The level design doesn‚Äôt get repetitive fast and there over 50 levels to complete.

The game‚Äôs sounds and music fit the style and while it is most certainly not as limited as many other platformers, some sounds do get repetitive eventually. Quite rare for a 2D platformer, are the presence of ingame cinematics Not once did the game steer away from it‚Äôs intended lycanthrope theme.

Pros
+ Classic type of gameplay
+ Horror and gore themes are well defined
+ Pleasant graphics and character sprites
+ Steam Trading Cards & Achievements


Cons
- It requires some trial and error
- The checkpoint save system is quite sparse
- A few repetitive sounds

Result / Final thoughts
This game never felt boring and while it did prove a bit difficult, the story was worth it. For a platformer, it mixed very well the gory elements along with combat sections and obstacle avoiding. The checkpoints could have been a bit more but once you get accustomed to the levels, passing them was never too hard. It is a game which knows it‚Äôs value and provides both Achievements and Trading Cards, making it a good addition to any Steam game collector and not just the nostalgic platforming gamers looking for a new challenge.

Rating 8/10

This review was submitted for Elite Giveaways, check us out for more reviews ranging from Indie games to AAA titles.

reviewText: I'm about halfway through the game, and I have enjoyed it immenesly thus far. As some of the other reviews have stated, this game can be incredibly difficult. I've played my fair share of difficult games, considering Dark Souls II is still my favorite game to date. This game has truly frustrated me, but I love it. This game has certain checkpoints, and once you die you will reset at said checkpoint. There is one point in the cave portion of the game, fairly early on, where there are sections that are rather long without checkpoints. You'll know what I mean. But overall, this is a well made and very unique experience, and I would recommend it to gamers looking for a challenge.

reviewText: Good game, though it has some minor flaws of sorts. Some of the checkpoints are either too close together or too far apart, and some of the challenges are almost TOO hard (like the flying challenge, especially condidering the distance between check points in that stage; or the all-white challenge inside the worm, though I generally enjoyed that). Another slightly annoying thing was the time it took for boss fights to start (maybe shorten the bosss' intro after the player's first death and respawn?) after dying and reterying repeatedly. Some of the aspects just felt like they took to long, especially since the player is probably going to die and have to retry kind of a lot. My final complaint is that it's a little short. Ultimately though, I enjoyed this game. I STRONGLY suggest playing the first part before this one (it's a free flash game; you should be able to find it by googling it). If you like the first part, then definetely consider giving this game a go.

reviewText: This game is one of the purest examples as game design as an artform that I can think of. The enthralling story and deep metaphorical implications force the player to think for themselves and reassess the world around them. reviewText: The prequel is called Vox Populi Vox Dei (a Werewolf Thriller) and it is a browser game. The changed a whole lot coming onto Steam. You can't jump over werewolves, you do frontflips for no reason at all and you can crawl. I don't know why they're called werewolves because they're just regular bipedal wolves. I don't know why the guy can do frontflips, I'm pretty sure he's not a ninja and you lose your invisibility ability not even halfway through the game. Another thing: you could easily beat this game in a day. I did it in somewhere around 3 hours. These may all seem like negative notes, but the game is actually really good. I really like the twist ending. It's challenging and a well-made sequel that doesn't ride on the prequel's success. Play the 1st one, then buy this.

reviewText:
I remember being younger and playing the original browser Flash version of this game (which I highly recommend you do before playing, as you may be a little bit lost if you don't (plus it's free.). This game is very similar to that one, but they just add a whole lot onto it.

There are parts where I thought this game was a little unfair with checkpoints and othersuch design choices, but mostly the new ideas that these guys bring foward outweigh those minor flaws.

I beat this game in under two hours, which is probably the biggest issue I had with this game. If it's on sale for $1.50USD or less, I would definitely pick it up if you enjoy platformers with tons of pixelated blood.

reviewText:
Textbook player-hostile design.

Even early in the game, everything seems to require almost frame-perfect timing.  A lot of seemingly simple rooms have incredibly unintuitive design that's going to kill you multiple times before you divine what the game really wants you to do.  Lots of elements seem to be timed specifically to kill a player who tries to move through quickly and smoothly, forcing you to wait.  Checkpoints are too infrequent for a game with this kind of difficulty, often requiring a player to re-complete a puzzle or sit through some auto-scrolling (seriously, every auto-scroller checkpoint has about three seconds of waiting after respawn for absolutely no reason) just to get back to where they died.  There's even at least one room that requires luck in order to complete.

Top it all off with some incredible tonal inconsistency that manages to make even the admittedly-good art design sometimes feel out-of-place, slippery controls that make the precise movements it demands impossible, and a shooter section with an incredibly unforgiving hitbox (and EVERY ENEMY BULLET will block yours and keep on going), and what we have here is something I would not recommend even this meager price for.

Go play the first one; you can find it online for free.  It is far, FAR better than this travesty.  Play that, and stay away from this one.

reviewText:
Vox Populi Vox Dei 2 is the sequel to a browser game released in 2009. It is available to play for free on Kongregate, but it would be awesome if it were available on Steam! Anywho, you are paying nothing compared to the amounts of fun and challenge this game can bring to yourself. The controls are smooth and 100% responsive, the art design is pleasant to one's eye, and the 60-ish levels available to play present various gameplay variety, never getting you bored.

I must say, killing werewolfs is amazing, as you watch all the blood come out (blood which is very well designed). The soundtrack is also a plus, and it's striking when a moment of action comes along.

Honestly, Vox Populi Vox Dei 2 should be more expensive. So everyone, do yourself a favor, by buying and playing through this rare gem! And also, an Episode 3 is in the works. Recommended!

Screenshot: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=522888174

reviewText:
I remember loving the original Vox Populi Vox Dei when I played it on Kongregate, so I was excited to see a sequel here on Steam for so cheap. Unfortunately, what we have here is a dull grind.

Cons:
- Sounds are mostly annoying and overlap, sometimes creating a deafening noise
- One-hit death in a world absolutely littered with hazards
- Face the same hazards over and over and over
- Enemies will pump you full of bullets if they even see the tip of your head
- Boss fights are boring - the first two consist of repeatedly rising on a platform and then leaping
- Melee-killing a wolf takes far too long (about 7 seconds of mashing the spacebar)
- Shifting, the only defensive mechanic, is taken away early in the game
- Checkpoints are sparse and weirdly placed
- The epic flying combat segment has poor controls, enemies that explode when shot, and projectiles that destroy yours without ever being destroyed. The best way to pass this part is to dodge and not fight back, taking the combat out of the only interesting combat level in the game.
- If you didn't enjoy the repetitive hazards, just wait until you have to control two characters through them simultaneously!

reviewText:
This is a great and really funny game. When I noticed about Dr. Wolf and his outfit I remembered Dr. No of James Bond saga. Here we don't have  a James Bond but a tiny ninja who wants his beloved back.
I loved the graphics, simple, right colors for the environment. And pixel art which I really like. Congratz to the Art designer!
The music.. I found the intro music and menu great but there's no music in the game. Music is something I personally appreciate in games, but the game is great so I can pass that.
And about the game, it's quite difficult! I lost the count of the times I killed the poor ninja. I should have an achievement for that. I love platform games, and this is one of the best I played in a good time!
Hope to see someday the first part of the story. :)

I leave my review here (Spanish).

https://youtu.be/KD-nVW9IOYU

reviewText: This game is probably one of the funnest platformers that you can pick up for little to nothing on steam. Coming in at just 3 usd on steam and under 1 when it's on sale, this game offers over 25 artistically designed levels that has a beatiful set up athmosphere thanks to the fantastic game soundtrack. You will find a few parts that may challenge you a bit but it's not as frustrating as something like super meatboy. A sequel game is in the works so if you pick this up and enjoy it you have that to look forward to. I suggest you buy this at your covenience and give it a try. Platformer lovers will not regret this purchase.

reviewText:
Vox 1 was my favorite flash game. The developer is a genius, fusing unique mechanics, fantastic artwork, puzzle elements, cool effects and a relentless pace which tells a story in-game, owing a lot to games like Another World or even Oddworld. The game feels like a very polished collection of those old flash games, which would give you a new mechanic and then let you toy with it for a few levels. I love the pace of this game, it might be incredibly frustrating, but clearing an area will reward you with almost an entirely new game straight afterwards. The level of artistry, originality.. its pretty rare and the developer has clear talent, there also can be a lot of careful nuance in the level design regarding pacing/reward/memorable moments.

But the game has some big issues. Mainly its sketchy collision hitboxes which rely on the entire sprites size (transparent areas around the actual graphics), instead of what you'd perceive to be the actual collision - and reliance on trial/error/memorization level design. The flying area, i feel, really doesn't belong in the game and lacks everything that makes the rest of the game interesting.

Overall, the experience is more than worth it, especially for this cheap price. The game has big flaws, but it has massive redeeming factors. There are also several hillarious moments, which i won't spoil.

reviewText:
I couldn't imagine how well crafted this little game would be.
No music. I don't even notice the lack of it - the game has it's own (kind of) depressing atmosphere and the gameplay is catching all attention. But for the boss fights there's music of course.
No speech. The story shows itself during cutscenes or during gameplay.
No text. Even when this game is about puzzles, it still shows it's potential to easely teach how to play levels on their first stages.
No water". Levels(sic) and story escalating quickly. Little to none gameplay repetition.
Even pixelated it looks mostly beautiful and even impressive. As I said before
date: this game is very well crafted for it's kind
recommended: the effort is noticable.\nIn my opinion

reviewText:
Nice and short platformer. The atmosphere is pretty weird, a strange doctor wolf kidnaps what appears to be your son and you have to rescue him.
The plaform controls are pretty good, I died a lot but there were no cheap deaths, mostly my mistakes.
The only section I wish they would change is when you fly on a bird and the game becomes sort of shoot 'em up, the bird moves painfully slow and it's impossible to dodge anything.
Controls are pretty good, I heard people complaint about them, but I quite liked them.
